USE JTest
--- bohs01@... wrote:

> Hi Ole,
> 
> 
> I found the update manager on the EMF website, both
> both URLs i used  
> came up with an error saying the installation is not
> comptible as i am  
> mising EMF 2.2.0 or EMF 2.3.0 ?
> 
> Am I missing something here? Isnt the url suppose to
> install EMF for me?
> 
> Confused,
> Jimm
> 
> 
> Quoting Ole Ersoy <ole_ersoy@...>:
> 
> > Hey Mate,
> >
> > Always glad to help.
> >
> > You are right - I tried downloading the sdk, and
> > I got a lot of jars inside the root eclipse
> directory,
> > along with 8 plugins for documentation, source
> code,
> > etc.
> >
> > I think Eclipse packages some plugins as
> straightup
> > jars now.  I noticed there are a gazillion raw jar
> > files in my installation plugins directory.
> >
> > If you unzip the contents of the eclipse folder
> into
> > your "eclipse" installation folder, everything
> should
> > install, as long as you have a compatible version.
> >
> > But also,
> >
> > There should be an automatic install for EMF via
> the
> > update site.
> >
> >
> > Help > Software Updates > Find and Install
> >
> > Select
> >
> > Search for new features to install
> >
> >
> >
> > It should find EMF for you.
> >
> > You probably want to flag the part about removing
> > overlapping plugins.
> >
> > I think that the updater pulls overlapping
> installs
> > from all the update sites, so that just removes
> the
> > overlaps.
> >
> > Once you have it installed, the Tutorial gives you
> all
> > the steps to add a JET nature to your project, and
> > from there you can play with JET.
> >
> > Also, the library EMF tutorial should give you
> > everything you need.  You download a version of
> the
> > library model (XML Schema, Ecore, Rose) and
> generate
> > an EMF Model from it.  Now you have a model that
> you
> > can pass to JET templates and play with.
> >
> > Let me know how it works out.
> >
> > Good luck and Happy New Year,
> > - Ole
> >
> >
> > --- junitheadache <bohs01@...>
> wrote:
> >
> >>
> >> I've dled the bundle from EMF website however
> I've
> >> no idea how to
> >> install it? I've unzipped it and its just a bunch
> of
> >> jar files?
> >>
> >> I am new to eclipse should I copy all of those
> files
> >> into the
> >> respective eclipse directory or something?
> >>
> >> Help needed,
> >> Jimm
> >>
> >>
> >> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ole Ersoy
> >> <ole_ersoy@...> wrote:
> >> >
> >> > You may also want to check out the Eclipse
> >> Modeling
> >> > Framework (EMF), as it generates stub tests for
> >> all of
> >> > it's model classes using JET templates.  This
> may
> >> > server as a good baseline to generate tests on
> top
> >> of.
> >> >
> >> > Also Ecore (The EMF Meta Modeling Framework) is
> >> useful
> >> > for thinking about the Semantics of Java and
> >> object
> >> > oriented structure.
> >> >
> >> > For example an EAttribrute is used to model
> >> primitives
> >> > in Java, as well as Strings.
> >> >
> >> > So if you start with models of what Java lets
> you
> >> do,
> >> > you can use those models to Enumerate all
> >> > possibilities and generate tests that test the
> >> > expectations around what is to be returned by
> >> method
> >> > calls and recommend various model invarient
> >> > constraints that would give feedback on illegal
> >> values
> >> > that would produce unwanted results.
> >> >
> >> > Alternatively if you use Java's Reflection
> >> > capabilities  that should get you a long ways
> as
> >> well.
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >> >
> >> > --- Kevin Lawrence <kev.lawrence@...> wrote:
> >> >
> >> > > On 12/27/06, junitheadache
> >> > > <bohs01@...> wrote:

> >> > > > assertFalse(isLegalInt(10));
> >> > > >
> >> > >

> *all*
> >> > > parameters to a
> >> > > method, for example:
> >> > >
> >> > > @Theory public void
> >> multiplyIsInverseOfDivide(Money
> >> > > amount, int multiplier) {
